column1: For purposes of this table, states were included if they mandated the listed actions. A number of states released guidance or recommendations related to the actions listed in this table but fell short of issuing a requirement and are thus not included.

For historical data, including dates of state actions, please see our [GitHub](https://github.com/KFFData/COVID-19-Data/tree/kff_master/State%20Policy%20Actions/State%20Social%20Distancing%20Actions) page.
1. The category totals for state face covering requirements may sum to more than 51 as some states may impose more than one type of requirement.

2. Beginning Aug. 11, non-residents entering Alaska from another state or country must submit a travel declaration with a negative COVID-19 test result 72 hours prior to departure, arrive with proof of a qualifying negative test, or purchase a test upon arrival and self-quarantine.
3. The gathering ban listed for these states refers to the lowest indoor limit in a majority of the state; there are higher limits for outdoor or other settings.

4. These states did not formally issue stay at home orders; however, other actions, including closing non-essential businesses, banning large gatherings, and issuing advisories urging residents to stay home, had the same effect. For these states, rolling back such measures is listed as easing/lifting the stay at home order.
5. Travelers to Hawaii may avoid the mandatory 14-day quarantine if they register with the state and provide a negative COVID-19 test conducted within 72 hours of their arrival.
6. Anyone entering a long-term care facility who is not a resident must wear a face mask.
7. New restrictions on large gatherings and restaurant and bar service in Illinois are requried in all regions in the state.
8. Any gathering of greater than 500 people must receive approval from the local health department.
9. Iowa limits gatherings to 50% of indoor or outdoor venue capacity and requires social distancing of 6 feet; if these requirements cannot be met, gatherings are limited to 10 people.

10. Face masks are required in indoor public spaces, state executive branch buildings, in bars and restaurants when not seated, and in other recreational venues (e.g., bowling alleys) when not seated to eat
11. Although the Governor has recommended pausing the move to phase out of the reopening plan, all businesses have reopened and the state has delegated decisionmaking authority to the local level.
12. Maine provides exceptions to the mandatory traveler quarantine based on negative COVID test results or travel from certain states.
13. Massachusetts limits gatherings indoors to eight people per 1,000 square feet, not to be greater than 25 people, and gatherings outdoors to 25% of facility capacity, not to exceed 100 people.
14. Mississippi reimposed a face mask requirement for the general public and limits on large gatherings in multiple counties across the state.
15. Face coverings are required in public indoor spaces and for organized outdoor activities when social distancing is not possible in counties with four or more active cases.

16. In Nebraska, groups at public venues are limited to no more than 8 people per table and venues that hold 500 or more people must get any reopening or capacity expansion plans approved by the local health department.
17. In addition to employees, these states require patrons/visitors in limited sectors to wear face coverings.

18. Counties determined to have Elevated Disease Transmission are subject to additional restrictions based on plans developed in conjunction with the Mitigation & Management Task Force. Currently, this impacts two counties. In one, large gatherings are limited to 50 people instead of the 250 person limit for the rest of the state, and in the other, county officials have cancelled all large gatherings over which they have authority.
19. Face coverings are required for all attendees of scheduled events with greater than 100 people present.
20. These states have closed restaurants for both indoor and outdoor dining, limiting them to take out and delivery only.

21. In New York, areas that have a high density of cases are subject to stricter policies, including closure of non-essential businesses, smaller caps on large gatherings, bar closures, and restaurant restrictions. As of November 9, this impacts seven areas.
22. Oklahoma requires people to wear face coverings on state property when social distancing cannot be maintained.
23. Face coverings are required in government buildings and restaurants, but local officials have the authority to mandate face coverings in other public places.
24. TN has implemented less restrictive orders that allow non-essential businesses and restaurants to reopen in 89 of the state’s 95 counties.
25. Bars may offer on-premises services at up to 50% capacity in hospital regions with low Covid-19 hospitalization rate.
26. Face masks required in counties with more than 20 COVID-19 cases.

27. Any individuals may not attend a social gathering unless the gathering has an event host or occurs at a business. Most counties are in Yellow (low level of restriction) phase with the exception of Salt Lake City which is still in the Orange phase (moderate). Thirteen counties are now in the Green (mimimal level of restriction) phase.

28. VA does not have a separate designation for bars, but bar areas of restaurants are closed, except for table seating. The on-site sale, consumption, and possession of alcohol is prohibited after 10:00 p.m.
29. Although most of the state is in Phase 2, some counties have been approved to move to Phase 3.
30. Except for counties in phase 3, bars remain closed and gatherings larger than five people are prohibited.
31. All social distancing restrictions were lifted by a WI Supreme Court ruling, not a decision by the Governor.
32. For schools providing on-site instruction, students, teachers, and school staff shall wear face coverings both indoors and outdoors where 6 feet of separation cannot be maintained.
